facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and decree of High Court of Patna dated 14th February 1946 in Appeal from Original Decree No. 117 of 1942 arising out of Title Suit No. 9 of 1939

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Appeal from a judgment and decree of the High Court of Judicature at Patna dated 14th February, 1946, in Appeal from Original Decree No. 117 of 1942 arising out

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 40 of 1950

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 40 of 1950. C. Misra for the appellant. C. Chatterjee  P. B. Gangoli, with him  for the re- spondent.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by MAHAJAN J. on February 5, 1951

anchor.surface_text: 1951. February 5. The judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by MAHAJAN J.--This appeal arises out of Suit No. 9 of 1939

facts.text: Suit No. 9 of 1939 instituted by appellants against respondents in Court of Subordinate Judge of Palamau for declarations re title to lands and injunction re rent suit

anchor.surface_text: ered by MAHAJAN J.--This appeal arises out of Suit No. 9 of 1939 instituted in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Palamau by the appellants against the respondents for a number of declarations in respect to the title to certain lands and for an injunction

facts.text: Suit decreed by Subordinate Judge but reversed by High Court of Patna, appellants' suit dismissed

anchor.surface_text: restraining the respondents from proceed- ing with a rent suit. The suit was decreed by the Subordi- nate Judge but on appeal this decision was reversed by the High Court of Judicature at Patna and the appellants suit was dismissed.

facts.text: Village Darha belonged to Pathaks family as ancestral lakhraj

anchor.surface_text: The salient facts of the case are as follows Village Darha belonged to a family of Pathaks as their ancestral lakhraj.

facts.text: Over a hundred years ago Pathaks granted entire village Darha in mokarrari to ancestors of Singha family (defendants first and second parties) at annual jama of Rs. 24

anchor.surface_text: Over a hundred years ago the Pathaks granted the entire village in mokarrari to the ancestors of the family of Singhas  defendants first and second parties  at an annual jams of Rs. 24.

facts.text: Mokarrari interest devolved on three branches: defendants first party (Parameshwar Dayal and others) 6 annas, defendants second party (Bisheswar Dayal Singh) 8 annas, Madho Saran Singh 2 annas

anchor.surface_text: The mokarrari interest eventually devolved on three branches of the Singha family, each branch getting in the following proportions Parameshwar Dayal and others, defendants first party, to the extent of six annas Bisheswar Dayal Singh, defendants second party, to the extent of eight annas and Madho Saran Singh, to the extent of two annas.

facts.text: Two anna share of Madho Saran Singh purchased by Hiranand Jha (father of plaintiffs) jointly with Durganand Jha and Dharam Dayal (benamidar for Hiranand)

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the two anna share of Madho Saran Singh was purchased by Hiranand Jha, father of the plaintiffs, jointly with. Durganand Jha and Dharam Dayal. Dharam Dayal was a mere benamidar for Hiranand Jha.

facts.text: On 5th June 1916, Bisheshwar Dayal Singh purchased six anna share in lakhraj interest from Deolal Pathak and others

anchor.surface_text: On the 5th June, 1916, Bisheshwar Dayal Singh purchased six anna share in the lakhraj interest from Deolal Pathak and others

facts.text: On 9th February 1917, Bisheshwar Dayal Singh purchased another two anna share from Mandil Pathak

anchor.surface_text: and on the 9th February, 1917, he purchased another two anna share from Mandil Pathak. By virtue of these purchases he came to own the lakhraj interest to the extent of eight anna share.

facts.text: Some time in 1917 or 1918 Hiranand Jha and Durganand Jha purchased in execution of rent decree the raiyati interest in whole village Darha and came into possession

anchor.surface_text: Some time in the year 1917 or 1918 Hiranand Jha and Durganand Jha, who had acquired by purchase two anna mokar- rari interest of Madho Saran Singh, purchased in execution of a rent decree the raiyati interest in the whole village and came into possession of it.

facts.text: Title Suit No. 59 of 1918 instituted in Subordinate Judge Palamau for partition by defendants first and second parties; Jhas impleaded

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1918, Title Suit No. 59 of 1918 was insti- tuted in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge of Palamau for partition of the lands situate in several villages and belonging to the family of the defendants first and second parties.

facts.text: Title Suit 59/1918 decreed in 1921; final partition allotted 2 annas Darha to Jhas, 14 annas excl khatian 1,3,6 to def first party, those khatians to Bisheshwar exchanged for property in Holeya

anchor.surface_text: This suit was decreed in the year 1921, and in the final partition an allotment of two annas share in Darha village was made in their favour. The remaining fourteen anna share excluding khatian 1, 3 and 6 was allotted to the defendants first party.

facts.text: In 1926 Pathaks and Bisheshwar Dayal Singh defaulted in cess payment to Government

anchor.surface_text: It appears that some time about the year 1926 the lakhraj interest holders, i.e., the Pathaks and Bisheshwar Dayal Singh, were in default in the payment of the cess due to Government.

facts.text: On 17th August 1926 proceedings taken against Pathaks and Bisheshwar for cess recovery; interest sold 18th October 1927 to Bijainandan Sahay

anchor.surface_text: On the 17th August, 1926, pro- ceedings were taken against them for recovery of the cess and their interest was sold in execution of a certificate on the 18th October, 1927, to one Bijainandan Sahay.

facts.text: Sale confirmed 19th December 1927, sale certificate issued 20th March 1928

anchor.surface_text: The sale obviously was of the lakhraj interest. This was companyfirmed on the 19th December, 1927, and a sale certificate was issued on the both March, 1928.

facts.text: Delivery of possession on 15th July 1928 to Kamta Prasad who acquired interest from Bijainandan Sahay on 20th April 1928

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by deliv- ery of possession on 15th July, 1928. Possession was ob- tained by one Kamta Prasad who had acquired this interest from Bijainandan Sahay on the 20th April, 1928.

facts.text: On 1st May 1933 Kamta Prasad transferred interest to plaintiffs; plaintiffs became proprietors of 16 annas, mokarraridars 2 annas, raiyats 16 annas

anchor.surface_text: On the 1st May, 1933, Kamta Prasad transferred his interest in the village to the plaintiffs who thus became proprietors of sixteen anna share in the village and mokarraridars as to two anna share and raiyats of the entire sixteen annas in the whole village.

facts.text: On 21st September 1934 defendants first party sued plaintiffs for rent arrears 1338-39F (6 annas), 1340-41F (14 annas)

anchor.surface_text: On the 21st September, 1934, the defendants first party as mokarraridars brought a suit against the plaintiffs for arrears of raiyati rent for the years 1338-39 F. to the extent of six annas share and for the years 134041 F. to the extent of fourteen anna share

facts.text: In 1934 rent suit, plaintiffs contested claiming merger of Bisheshwar's 8 anna mokarrari in lakhraj; decree for full rent upheld on appeals, title left open

anchor.surface_text: Plaintiffs companytested the suit alleging-that Bisheshwars mokarrari interest had merged in the lakhraj interest that was purchased by him from the Pathaks in the years 1916-17, and that by the sale under the Governments certificate his whole eight anna interest in the village including both the lakhraj and the mokarrari had passed on to the plaintiffs

facts.text: In 1938 defendants first party filed another rent suit for post-fasli 1341

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1938 another suit for rent was filed by the defendants first party as mokarraridars to recover fourteen anna share of the rent for the years subsequent to fasli 1341.

facts.text: Plaintiffs alleged private partition between mokarraridars dividing lands of Darha

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint, it was alleged that there was a private partition between the mokarraridars by virtue of which the lands of village Darha were divided between the three sets of mokarraridars, each set being in separate possession of its own separate and defined shares.

facts.text: Plaintiffs alleged partition between lakhraj proprietors: lands in certain patties fell to Deolal Pathak etc., others to Bisheshwar

anchor.surface_text: It was also pleaded that there was another parti- tion between the proprietors of the lakhrai interest, that is, between Bisheshwar Dayal Singh on the one hand and Deolal Pathak, Neman Pathak and Surajnath Pathak on the other,

facts.text: Trial Judge (Subordinate Judge) held both partitions proved, merger occurred, defendants first party entitled only to 6 anna rent

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge held that both the partitions alleged by the plaintiffs in paragraphs 5 and 8 of their plaint were proved and that the mokarrari interest of Bisheshwar Dayal Singh merged in his lakhraj interest

facts.text: High Court held neither partition proved, no merger possible, dismissed plaintiffs' suit

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in appeal held that numbere of the partitions alleged by the plaintiffs were proved and that the mokarrari interest of eight annas companyld number merge in the lakhrai interest of sixteen annas held jointly by Bisheshwar Dayal Singh with the Pathaks.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no scope for doctrine of merger on plaintiffs' own case

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this appeal can be disposed of on a short point without taking into companysideration the respective companytentions of the parties raised before us or urged in the two companyrts below.

It, however, seems to us that there was no scope for the application of the doctrine of merger to the facts disclosed by the plaintiffs in their plaint. If the lessor purchases the lessees interest, the lease no doubt is extinguished as the same man cannot at the same time be both a landlord and a tenant, but there is no extinction of the lease if one of the several lessees purchases only a part of the lessors interest. In such a case the leasehold and the reversion cannot be said to coincide.

concepts.interpretation: Applies only when entire lessor and lessee interests coincide in one person; no merger where one co-lessee acquires only partial reversionary interest, as interests do not coalesce completely.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: bility qua the lessor for the payment of the whole rent, as several tenants of a tenancy in law companystitute but a single tenant, and qua the landlo

concepts.unlisted_description: Principle extinguishing inferior interest when it merges into superior interest held by same person.

concepts.interpretation: Exists between tenant and landlord for the whole leasehold, making joint tenants liable jointly for covenants.
concepts.unlisted_description: Legal relationship binding successors to lease covenants.

anchor.surface_text: Mere purchase by Bisheshwar Dayal Singh of portions of the lakhraj interest could not bring about an extinction of the lease or break its integrity as he was only one of the several joint holders of the mokarrari interest.

concepts.interpretation: Integrity of lease not broken by partial purchases or inter se partitions among co-tenants; does not create separate tenancies without fresh contract.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: it up owners of the holding and the different owners in the mokarrari interest. The lakhraj holding in the village still remains a single holding and

concepts.unlisted_description: Principle preserving unity of tenancy despite internal divisions among co-holders.

concepts.interpretation: Co-tenants under one lease treated as single tenant vis-a-vis landlord; inter se partition does not alter joint obligations or create multiple tenancies.
concepts.unlisted_description: Joint tenants form one legal tenant against landlord for rent and covenants.

anchor.surface_text: Dharam Dayal was a mere benamidar for Hiranand Jha.

concepts.unlisted_description: Benami holding where name lender holds for real owner.

issues.text: whether there was scope for the application of the doctrine of merger to the facts disclosed by the plaintiffs in their plaint

anchor.surface_text: It, however, seems to us that there was no scope for the application of the doctrine of merger to the facts disclosed by the plaintiffs in their plaint. If the lessor purchases the lessees interest, the lease no doubt is extinguished as the same man cannot at the same time be both a landlord and a tenant, but there is no extinction of the lease if one of the several lessees purchases only a part of the lessors interest.

issues.text: whether mere purchase by Bisheshwar Dayal Singh of portions of the lakhraj interest could bring about an extinction of the lease or break its integrity

anchor.surface_text: Mere purchase by Bisheshwar Dayal Singh of portions of the lakhraj interest could not bring about an extinction of the lease or break its integrity as he was only one of the several joint holders of the mokarrari interest.

issues.text: whether an inter se partition of the mokarrari interest amongst the mokarraridars could affect their liability qua the lessor for the payment of the whole rent or the integrity of the lease

anchor.surface_text: An inter se partition of the mokarrari interest amongst the mokarraridars as alleged by the plaintiffs could not affect their liability qua the lessor for the payment of the whole rent, as several tenants of a tenancy in law constitute but a single tenant, and qua the landlord they constitute one person, each constituent part of which possesses certain common rights in the whole and is liable to discharge common obligations in its entirety.

issues.text: whether there is privity of estate between joint tenants and landlord making them liable for covenants in the whole leasehold
whether the two partitions set up by the plaintiffs in paragraphs 5 and 8 of the plaint were proved

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal it was contended by the learned counsel for the appellants that the High Court had erroneously held that the two partitions set up by the plaintiffs in paragraphs 5 and 8 had not been proved. It was argued that the evidence on the record, both documentary and oral, fully established the fact of the two partitions and that in view of these partitions it should have been held that Bisheshwar Dayal Singh became separate owner of eight anna lakhraj interest and in that interest his mokarrari interest of eight annas merged,

arguments.claim: Bisheshwar Dayal Singh's mokarrari interest merged in the lakhraj interest purchased by him from the Pathaks, and by the certificate sale his whole eight anna interest passed to the plaintiffs

anchor.surface_text: Plaintiffs contested the suit alleging-that Bisheshwars mokarrari interest had merged in the lakhraj interest that was purchased by him from the Pathaks in the years 1916-17, and that by the sale under the Governments certificate his whole eight anna interest

arguments.court_reasoning: No scope for merger as interests did not fully coincide

arguments.claim: No scope for doctrine of merger as one lessee purchasing part of lessor's interest does not extinguish lease since leasehold and reversion do not coincide

anchor.surface_text: It, however, seems to us that there was no scope for the application of the doctrine of merger to the facts disclosed by the plaintiffs in their plaint. If the lessor purchases the lessees interest, the lease no doubt is extinguished as the same man cannot at the same time be both a landlord and a tenant, but there is no extinction

arguments.claim: Bisheshwar never owned entire lakhraj or entire mokarrari interest, so no coalescence

anchor.surface_text: He, however, never came to own the entire lakhraj interest in the village or the entire mokarrari interest therein. There was thus no coalescence of the interest of the lessor and the lessee in the whole of the estate which was subject to lakhraj and mokarrari interests

arguments.claim: Mere purchase of portions of lakhraj by one joint mokarrari holder does not extinguish lease or break its integrity

anchor.surface_text: Mere purchase by Bisheshwar Dayal Singh of portions of the lakhraj interest could not bring about an extinction of the lease or break its integrity as he was only one of the several joint holders of the mokarrari interest.

arguments.claim: Inter se partition among mokarraridars does not affect liability for whole rent as co-tenants constitute single tenant qua lessor
Privity of estate exists between joint tenants and landlord for whole leasehold, binding for all covenants
Inter se partitions do not sever tenancy or create separate tenancies absent fresh contract; lakhraj remains single holding sold as whole

holdings.text: there was no scope for the application of the doctrine of merger to the facts disclosed by the plaintiffs in their plaint

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs case rests solely on the allegation of merger of the eight anna lakhraj interest of Bisheshwar Dayal Singh with his mokarrari interest to the same extent. It, however, seems to us that there was no scope for the application of the doctrine of merger to the facts disclosed by the plaintiffs in their plaint.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine of merger requires complete extinction where lessor acquires entire lessee interest or vice versa; partial acquisition by one co-lessee does not cause coalescence of entire interests

holdings.text: Mere purchase by Bisheshwar Dayal Singh of portions of the lakhraj interest could not bring about an extinction of the lease or break its integrity as he was only one of the several joint holders of the mokarrari interest

anchor.surface_text: There was thus no coalescence of the interest of the lessor and the lessee in the whole of the estate which was subject to lakhraj and mokarrari interests and that being so, the mokarrari interest of Bisheshwar Dayal Singh did not merge in his lakhraj interest. Mere purchase by Bisheshwar Dayal Singh of portions of the lakhraj interest could not

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partial purchase by one joint tenant does not extinguish lease since full reversionary and leasehold interests do not unite in single holder

holdings.text: An inter se partition of the mokarrari interest amongst the mokarraridars as alleged by the plaintiffs could not affect their liability qua the lessor for the payment of the whole rent, as several tenants of a tenancy in law constitute but a single tenant

anchor.surface_text: Mere purchase by Bisheshwar Dayal Singh of portions of the lakhraj interest could not bring about an extinction of the lease or break its integrity as he was only one of the several joint holders of the mokarrari interest. An inter se partition of the mokarrari interest amongst the mokarraridars as alleged by the plaintiffs could not affect their liability

holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint tenants under single lease form one legal tenant against landlord; internal partitions do not alter joint obligations or lease unity

holdings.text: There is a privity of the estate between the tenant and the landlord in the whole of the leasehold and he is liable for all the covenants running with the land
holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint tenants bound by privity for entire leasehold covenants, citing precedent; supports single tenancy concept

holdings.text: In law, therefore, an inter se partition of the mokarrari interest could not affect the integrity of the lease and it could not be said that Bisheshwar Dayal Singh under the alleged partition became a mokarraridar under another contract of lease
holdings.reasoning_summary: Inter se partitions for convenience do not sever tenancy or imply new leases without fresh contract; preserves lease integrity

holdings.text: none of the conditions necessary for the application of the doctrine of merger can be said to have been made out by the allegations made in the plaint
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiffs' plaint allegations fail to satisfy merger requirements; lease remains extant for six annas share

anchor.surface_text: White v. Tyndall 1 , the parties to whom a demise is made hold as tenants in companymon but what they companyenant to pay is one rent, number two rents and number each to pay half a rent but one rent. There is a privity of the estate between the tenant and the landlord in the whole of the leasehold and he is liable for all the companyenants running with the land. In law, therefore, an inter se partition of the mokarrari interest companyld number affect the integrity of the lease and it companyld number be said that Bisheshwar Dayal Singh under the alleged partition became a mokarraridar under another company- tract of lease.

precedents.cited_proposition: parties to whom a demise is made hold as tenants in common but what they covenant to pay is one rent, not two rents and not each to pay half a rent but one rent
precedents.cited_holding: the parties to whom a demise is made hold as tenants in common but what they covenant to pay is one rent, not two rents and not each to pay half a rent but one rent

anchor.surface_text: All owners  1  13 App. Cas. 263 of the lakhraj interest are jointly responsible for payment of the cess to Government and it was because of their de- fault in payment of the cess that the whole lakhraj interest was sold in the certificate sale. In this situation numbere of the companyditions necessary for the application of the doctrine of merger can be said to have been made out by the allega- tions made in the plaint. On the plaintiffs own case the lease is still a live one in respect of the six anna inter- est of the defendants first party and in these circum- stances it is number possible to hold that it has become ex- tinct to the extent of eight anna interest of Bisheshwar Dayal Singh in the absence of any allegation that any fresh companytract, express or implied, was arrived at between the parties.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal rejected as doctrine of merger not applicable to the facts; no declaration or injunction granted to appellants
